line_item.description: HRV, ductwork and all associated appurtenances
line_item.notes: Located on roof near gridline B.

line_item.description: Outside air intakes, roof vents, and roof relief hoods
line_item.specifications: Demolish as necessary. Verify size and configuration prior to ordering new vents.
line_item.notes: Multiple locations shown on plan M1.2.

line_item.specifications: Fabricate and install 2"x framed doghouse, 24"x24"x32" tall interior dimensions. Coordinate with roofer for flashing.
line_item.notes: For new exhaust fans EF-1 and EF-3.

line_item.specifications: Provide with wall cap with integral backdraft damper (BDD).
line_item.notes: For existing fans EF-4 and EF-5 which are to remain.

line_item.specifications: An independent air balancing company will perform the air balancing of the complete heating and HVAC systems per the SMACNA balancing and adjustment manual.
line_item.notes: This is a required third-party service.

line_item.description: Insulation for Interior Rain Leader Piping
line_item.specifications: Fiberglass pipe insulation with factory applied all-service jacket; 1.0-inch thickness.
line_item.notes: Applies to all new interior rain leader and overflow piping.

line_item.specifications: Test the rainleader systems per the Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC).
Replace existing 300A main breaker with new 400A main breaker in existing main distribution panel.
line_item.notes: Field verify existing equipment for compatibility.

line_item.specifications: Replace existing feeder from main disconnect to Panel 'A' as shown on oneline diagram. New feeder: 3#500kcmil, #500kcmil N, #2G in 4"C.

updates.notes: Quantity takeoff from plan A1.2. Each set includes one primary roof drain and one overflow drain.

updates.specifications: Provide and install new RTU on new field-fabricated insulated roof curb. Coordinate with roofer for flashing. Provide turning vanes in elbows for duct transitions as detailed.
updates.notes: Applies to RTU-1 through RTU-6. Curbs are field fabricated per details on M2.3.

Includes disconnects at each unit. Per Addendum 1, the electrical loads of the submitted RTUs exceed the basis of design. Contractor must coordinate with electrical and include costs for any required circuit modifications (upsizing breakers, conductors).

gaps_identified.gap: Exact lengths of new gas piping and sizes for each run are not quantified and require a manual takeoff from sheet M2.3.
Linear footage of all new interior rain leader and overflow piping (3" and 4") requires a manual takeoff from sheet M2.2.
Conduit and wire lengths for all new equipment connections require a manual takeoff from sheet E3.0.
The exact scope of re-routing existing circuits from demolished Panel 'X' to new Panel 'D' is not detailed and will require field investigation to determine lengths and complexity.

ai_observations.title: Electrical Load Discrepancy for New RTUs
ai_observations.insight: Addendum No. 1 includes a Mechanical Submittal Review from Jernstrom Engineering which explicitly states that the submitted equipment loads for all new RTUs (RTU-1 through RTU-6) exceed the basis of design loads. It directs the contractor to coordinate with the electrical trade. This implies that the existing branch circuits shown to be reused on the electrical plans may be undersized for the new equipment. The cost to upsize breakers and potentially pull new, larger conductors from the panels to the roof units could be significant and must be included in the bid.
suggested_actions: The Electrical subcontractor must review the electrical requirements of the selected RTUs against the existing circuit sizes shown on the plans.
Include costs for upsizing breakers and conductors for all new RTUs as a necessary part of the base bid and additive alternates.
Submit an RFI to confirm the extent of the required electrical upgrades if the new loads are not provided prior to bid.

ai_observations.title: Heat Trace System Coordination
ai_observations.insight: The project requires a new heat trace system for the rain leaders and overflow leaders. The Electrical scope (E3.0, E4.0) includes providing the Raychem system and power connection. The Plumbing scope (M2.2) includes installing the pipes. The Civil scope (C1.0) shows the exterior portion of the system. Coordination is required to ensure the correct type of piping is used that is compatible with the heat trace system, and that installation is sequenced correctly. The plumber must install the pipe, then the electrician installs the heat trace, before the plumber can insulate the pipe.
suggested_actions: Hold a pre-construction meeting between the Plumbing and Electrical subcontractors to review the heat trace installation sequence and requirements.
Confirm responsibility for any required sleeves or access points for the heat trace system.
Verify the total linear footage of pipe requiring heat trace from a combined review of M2.2 and C1.0.

ai_observations.title: Field Verification Required for Electrical Panel Work
ai_observations.insight: The electrical scope includes major modifications to the main distribution system, including replacing a main breaker, replacing a feeder to Panel 'A', demolishing Panel 'X', and adding new Panels 'D' and 'MECH'. The one-line diagram is schematic and the physical constraints, existing conductor conditions, and available space in the electrical room are unknown. This work carries a high risk of unforeseen conditions.
suggested_actions: A mandatory pre-bid site visit by the Electrical subcontractor is essential to assess the existing electrical room, panel clearances, and feeder routing.
Include a contingency in the electrical bid for potential difficulties in re-routing circuits from Panel 'X' to 'D' and for making new connections in the existing main switchgear.
Verify the brand and type of existing gear to ensure compatibility of the new 400A main breaker.

overall_assessment.summary: The deep-dive analysis of the Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing trades confirms a well-defined but complex scope. Key additions include HVAC testing/balancing, pipe insulation, and significant electrical distribution upgrades like a main breaker replacement. The primary risk identified is the electrical load discrepancy for all new RTUs, as highlighted in an addendum, which will likely require upsizing circuits and feeders beyond what is explicitly shown on the base drawings. This, along with the need for extensive field verification for the panel work, elevates the project risk. Coordination for the heat trace system and rooftop equipment sequencing is also critical. The initial extraction was solid but missed these nuanced details and risks embedded in the specifications and addenda.
